message:
Salam ALLAH
I want to ask about Angular and SEO ?!! :)
Currently we are working on a big eCommerce website and i preferred to use Angular, signalR and some of technologies but i surprised when i got a recommendation from one of the biggest SEO companies on the glob that they asked me what about if the user disabled his java script?!!!
I got confused shall i repeat my work again to overcome that issue!!
Please advise  :(

data.message: What is the percentage of those who disable javascript? answer this question then decide.

The question isn't who is disabling JavaScript ... The question is how search engines would crawl a website that is heavily dependent on JavaScript ... I would recommend you check this article http://www.yearofmoo.com/2012/11/angularjs-and-seo.html
Although I would generally go against using Angular for the whole eCommerce solution. Perhaps use it in some parts (filtering, search ...) not the whole thing
really i don't know but, that issue takes the highest priority from that SEO company :(

And they are right ... if you are building a tool like Basecamp, Harvest or anything that shouldn't be crawled I would say go for Angular or any other JS frameworks ... But Angular for an eCommerce? Hell no :D You will definitely face a lot of challenges to make it work + you will have to do a lot of work to prefetch and render on the server if a crawling bot tried to access the website. Good luck
Disable Java Script Disable Internet Connection

I did little bit investigation on this subject before and I've also implemented a small proof of concept. 
First :Google started gradually to index the websites that use javascript in rendering 
http://googlewebmastercentral.blogspot.com/2014/05/understanding-web-pages-better.html?m=1

Second, for the other search engines, as per the seo standards,  they change the part of the url that is used by the js libraries (!#) so simply you can intercept the httprequest that is coming from the search engine crawler and pre-fetch the page thin give it as loaded html to the search engine. You can use PhantomJs to do so.

http://phantomjs.org
(!#)  = hashbangs ... Twitter used it before but ditched them now.
Please let me know if you need further support.
Search engines definitely are executing java script, there is even a project called phantom JS, that lets you run a web page' js and get the result document

If your business relies heavily on search engines and you also want to provide good user experience, you might want to consider making search engines traffic get a slightly different treatment, for example using when search engines hit your website run it through PhantomJS to execute the markup

And there are few open source implementation already available.
http://backbonetutorials.com/seo-for-single-page-apps/
https://www.npmjs.com/package/seoserver
Amr Magdy I think you can help here

Google started executing the js but still as beta i think,

* from monitoring Google boats : 
 they do 2 requests for the pages that contains Ajax one with executing the js for the normal page and another one with the !# replacement or fragment tag way 

* from the simulation of Google crawler provided by Google:
they execute the js without the !# replacement or the fragment tag

note that : better to use !#  than fragment tag , as i noticed that when i use fragment tag it doesn't execute the js first time and executes the second time, but when i use !# it executes the js from the first time
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
*in my view  it is better if you detect the crawler with the !# and use phantomJS to execute the js on the server ( if the user is a crawler ) so you will be sure that it will work whatever they search engine support js executing or not. and make both methods result are SEO friendly not only the output of the phantomjs method.
Why don't ecommerce websites use Magento or Shopify ?
^ cause sometimes you need to reinvent the wheel and create something with your own flavor. That's something good actually :D
But this also means that you'll pay to damn much to do something that was already done and reviewed and debugged.
